review.title: Software Effort Estimation with Ridge Regression and Evolutionary Attribute Selection
review.abstract: Software cost estimation is one of the prerequisite managerial activities carried out at the software development initiation stages and also repeated throughout the whole software life-cycle so that amendments to the total cost are made. In software cost estimation typically, a selection of project attributes is employed to produce effort estimations of the expected human resources to deliver a software product. However, choosing the appropriate project cost drivers in each case requires a lot of experience and knowledge on behalf of the project manager which can only be obtained through years of software engineering practice. A number of studies indicate that popular methods applied in the literature for software cost estimation, such as linear regression, are not robust enough and do not yield accurate predictions. Recently the dual variables Ridge Regression (RR) technique has been used for effort estimation yielding promising results. In this work we show that results may be further improved if an AI method is used to automatically select appropriate project cost drivers (inputs) for the technique. We propose a hybrid approach combining RR with a Genetic Algorithm, the latter evolving the subset of attributes for approximating effort more accurately. The proposed hybrid cost model has been applied on a widely known high-dimensional dataset of software project samples and the results obtained show that accuracy may be increased if redundant attributes are eliminated.
histories: 3d Artificial Intelligence Techniques in Software Engineering Workshop, 7 October, 2010, Larnaca, Cyprus
review.COMMENTS: 3d Artificial Intelligence Techniques in Software Engineering Workshop, 7 October, 2010, Larnaca, Cyprus

metadata.title: Software Effort Estimation with Ridge Regression and Evolutionary Attribute Selection

sections.text: Software cost estimation typically uses a selection of project attributes to generate estimates of expected human resource expenditure to deliver a software product. However, selecting suitable project cost drivers always requires a lot of experience and knowledge on the part of the project manager, which can only be gained through years of software engineering practice. Recently, a number of studies have suggested that popular methods used in the literature to estimate software costs, such as linear regression, are not robust enough and do not provide accurate predictions. Recently, the Dual Variable Ridge Regression (RR) method has been used to estimate expenditure, which yields promising results. In this paper, we show that results can be further improved if an AI method is used to automatically select suitable project cost drivers (inputs) for the technology. We propose a hybrid approach that combines RR with a genetic algorithm, with the latter set of software being developed to approximate the attributes.

sections.heading: 3 Dual Variables Ridge Regression
sections.text: The Ridge Regression (RR) is an improvement of the classical least squares technique, which is one of the prevailing methods in the estimation of software costs and one of the most commonly used regression algorithms in a large number of research areas, such as predicting ionospheric parameters [18], environmental risk assessment [19] and facial recognition [20]. In this thesis, we use the method of dual variables RR proposed in [21], since it uses core functions to enable the construction of nonlinear regressions without having to perform expensive compressions in a high-dimensional feature space. In order to approximate a number of sample projects, the well-known RR procedure recommends a series of projects {(x1, y1) in which xi n is the vector of attributes (cost drivers) for the i and yi projects, the known RR procedure (the known RR-positive method) in the 12velw-1 (the preceding method).

sections.heading: 4 Genetically Evolved Cost Driver Subsets
sections.text: A group of individuals develops, each pursuing a specific goal.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Results
sections.text: The proposed genetically engineered software cost driver algorithm was implemented using the MATLAB genetic algorithm (R2008b) and the Direct Search Toolbox [22] and had a twofold objective: firstly, to select the best subset of cost drivers from a larger pool of drivers, and secondly, to minimize the relative error rate of the RR technique. The ISBSG dataset used in the experiments contained a large number of project attributes relating to the application domain, the programming language used, the language type, the development technology, the resource level, the functional size of the software generated, etc. The dataset contained numerical, categorical, multi-category and zero values, and so we performed the following column and row filtering actions by: a) excluded attributes measured after the project was completed and therefore not feasible for the cost model for the remaining attributes, and we excluded the number of data.

sections.heading: 5.2 Results
sections.text: The summary statistics of the output (depending on) of the variables used in the experiments are presented in Table 1. Figures show large differences between the actual data used for the estimate. To test the performance of the proposed approach, we randomly divided the data set into training and testing kits 10 times, with 80% of the projects each included in the training and the remaining 20% in the testing kits. Our DG was then applied to each of the resulting training sessions with a population of 100 generations producing the selected cost drivers for the corresponding partition. The selected cost drivers were then used as inputs for training the RTD technology and the evaluation of their cost estimates for the training. The attributes obtained are used in the developed subset of selected cost drivers for the corresponding partition.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: This work suggested the use of the dual variable Ridge Regression (RR) technique in conjunction with a Genetic Algorithm (GA) to develop the selection of cost drivers to be used as input factors for estimating software expenditure. An important advantage of using a GA is that it can efficiently search the vast space of possible combinations of cost drivers and achieve a near-optimal result. Results from the evaluation phase of our experiments show that the proposed algorithm has not only reduced the number of cost drivers used to less than half, but has also led to an improvement in the performance of the dual variable RR technique. In the future, we plan to further investigate the impact that each cost driver has on the resulting predictions that allow for data sets other than coding decisions.

Our previous work has targeted the production of reliable confidence measures based on the dual form Ridge Regression (RR) technique [2] where it was suggested that results could be improved if the most relevant project attributes were selected and engaged in the prediction process.

Specifically, RR has been used to estimate the coefficients for the COCOMO model [3], one of the most widely known cost models, to produce classification scores and remove unnecessary features [4] and to improve the performance of regressions on multi-collinear datasets [5].

These models require usually a wealth of data and make use of numerical transformations to achieve accurate and reliable effort estimates [6].
The most common parametric estimation models, such as the COCOMO, use linear regression to approximate effort [7].
In [8] the accuracy of the COCOMO was improved when a wrapper technique was used to identify the most promising features for the model.
Other Feature Subset Selection (FSS) algorithms were investigated for increasing the accuracy performance in analogy-based software effort estimation models [9].
In [10] Genetic Algorithms (GA) were used to assign proper weights to features, and three different heuristics were proposed to increase the estimation performance.

The popularity of research on alternative models has increased, according to systematic reviews [7], even though the obtained results are always compared to those of linear regression techniques as a baseline.

As previously mentioned, the largest portion of research studies in cost estimation are using linear regression as the most applicable method which also serves as benchmark for assessing performance in terms of accuracy [7].
